snippet.textDisplay:
@Alcone Punch Last thing he did music score for was Grandia Online for Windows. Back in 2009 there were rumours about Grandia IV is in the works for PS3 but I know it wasn't true since Game Arts was busy with the online servers of Grandia Online and I asked them in 2011 if they will work on consoles again and the answer I got was "unfortunately there are no plans at the moment". So in 2012 they shut down servers for Grandia Online and Iwadare is 50 years old today. Whatever Gungho decides to do a new entry in the Grandia series is up in the air. If Suikoden and Wild Arms can brought to life so can Grandia. Lunar on the other hand will never get a Lunar 3, sadly. That series will probably be remade again.

The only problem with GungHo is their heavily focus on online games. Look at Grasshopper when they were purchased by GungHo. That game Let it die is a free to play and it's a online game. I have no hopes for a full fledged Grandia game anytime soon.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Alcone Punch Last thing he did music score for was Grandia Online for Windows. Back in 2009 there were rumours about Grandia IV is in the works for PS3 but I know it wasn't true since Game Arts was busy with the online servers of Grandia Online and I asked them in 2011 if they will work on consoles again and the answer I got was "unfortunately there are no plans at the moment". So in 2012 they shut down servers for Grandia Online and Iwadare is 50 years old today. Whatever Gungho decides to do a new entry in the Grandia series is up in the air. If Suikoden and Wild Arms can brought to life so can Grandia. Lunar on the other hand will never get a Lunar 3, sadly. That series will probably be remade again.

The only problem with GungHo is their heavily focus on online games. Look at Grasshopper when they were purchased by GungHo. That game Let it die is a free to play and it's a online game. I have no hopes for a full fledged Grandia game anytime soon.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Giordan Diodato
That's because PC is the hardest platform to develop for thanks to the huge variety of potential hardware combinations people can have, and until recently it's had dramatically fewer users than consoles. More time and difficulty + less funding = shitty ports.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Giordan Diodato
That's because PC is the hardest platform to develop for thanks to the huge variety of potential hardware combinations people can have, and until recently it's had dramatically fewer users than consoles. More time and difficulty + less funding = shitty ports.

snippet.textDisplay: if you're talking tech, let me remind you that final fantasy didn't have voice acting till ffx, that is inexcusable for a high budget title. of course professional voice actors were scarce at that point but heck, voice acting today is of a poor standard but grandia 2 managed to have some of the best voice acting for it's time and it put it in the right places so that it isn't fully dubbed which i actually liked, i hate full dubs (there are exceptions) i'd rather interpret the dialogue in my mind
snippet.textOriginal: if you're talking tech, let me remind you that final fantasy didn't have voice acting till ffx, that is inexcusable for a high budget title. of course professional voice actors were scarce at that point but heck, voice acting today is of a poor standard but grandia 2 managed to have some of the best voice acting for it's time and it put it in the right places so that it isn't fully dubbed which i actually liked, i hate full dubs (there are exceptions) i'd rather interpret the dialogue in my mind

snippet.textDisplay: FFVII was released a mere 3 years into the life of the original Playstation, making it one of the system's earliest major titles. Its graphics were also exceptional by genre standards of the time. On the other hand, Grandia II was released on the Dreamcast in 2000, with the port showing up 2 years later, with visual design worse than many PS1 games.
snippet.textOriginal: FFVII was released a mere 3 years into the life of the original Playstation, making it one of the system's earliest major titles. Its graphics were also exceptional by genre standards of the time. On the other hand, Grandia II was released on the Dreamcast in 2000, with the port showing up 2 years later, with visual design worse than many PS1 games.

snippet.textDisplay:
What sources are you drawing on to call the game "widely credited" for revolutionizing RPG battle systems? Because I have heard no such thing, and would have to disagree with the sentiment after having played through the game myself.

Granted, some of the ideas presented in the original Grandia were novel in their time; in particular, the fact that characters' attacks can interact to form combos or interrupt enemy attacks. But saying that it revolutionized RPGs is giving it undue credit.
snippet.textOriginal:
What sources are you drawing on to call the game "widely credited" for revolutionizing RPG battle systems? Because I have heard no such thing, and would have to disagree with the sentiment after having played through the game myself.

Granted, some of the ideas presented in the original Grandia were novel in their time; in particular, the fact that characters' attacks can interact to form combos or interrupt enemy attacks. But saying that it revolutionized RPGs is giving it undue credit.

snippet.textDisplay:
You just said the gameplay was boring and added nothing to the genre, when it's widely credited for revolutionizing how RPG battle systems could be.

Like, what? Come on, you can not like the game, but at least attack some weak parts of the game, when you're attacking things that it's gotten awards for doing.
snippet.textOriginal:
You just said the gameplay was boring and added nothing to the genre, when it's widely credited for revolutionizing how RPG battle systems could be.

Like, what? Come on, you can not like the game, but at least attack some weak parts of the game, when you're attacking things that it's gotten awards for doing.

snippet.textDisplay:
This game is in no way superior to FFVII. The sound work was atrocious, (even if, as this song proves, some of the music was good,) the environments and character models were ugly, the story was a predictable snoozefest, and the gameplay was boring and added nothing to the genre.

While I agree with the sentiment that FFVII gets way more hype than it deserves, you're wrong if you think this game is better. You may have enjoyed it more, but it remains demonstrably worse.
snippet.textOriginal:
This game is in no way superior to FFVII. The sound work was atrocious, (even if, as this song proves, some of the music was good,) the environments and character models were ugly, the story was a predictable snoozefest, and the gameplay was boring and added nothing to the genre.

While I agree with the sentiment that FFVII gets way more hype than it deserves, you're wrong if you think this game is better. You may have enjoyed it more, but it remains demonstrably worse.

snippet.textDisplay: i Can kinda help you with that question. In Game Informers November 2012 issue they have a section titled "Lost RPG Franchises: Where are they now?," and Grandia was one of the series mentioned in it. To quote the writer: "With Grandia Online shutting down(Sept. 2009) and developer GameArts working on GungHo's Ragnarok titles, we're not likely to see a new Grandia any time soon."

snippet.textDisplay: Even though you asked a year ago, I think it's fair to weigh in for those who are thinking about this game: it is an imensely well-delivered narrative, with townsfolk who have (at least for the time of release) an impressive amount of additional dialogue to absorb. The battle-system is dynamic and compelling enough to feel a step ahead of most JRPGs, ultimately making its contemporary FF games feel extremely easy in comparison. Low points? Not much exploration, and highly limited back-tracking.
snippet.textOriginal: Even though you asked a year ago, I think it's fair to weigh in for those who are thinking about this game: it is an imensely well-delivered narrative, with townsfolk who have (at least for the time of release) an impressive amount of additional dialogue to absorb. The battle-system is dynamic and compelling enough to feel a step ahead of most JRPGs, ultimately making its contemporary FF games feel extremely easy in comparison. Low points? Not much exploration, and highly limited back-tracking.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ah, the Zera Valmar fight. I always liked the irony in Zera's name... You know, Pope Zera Innocentus. I loved this fight for multiple reasons.
One: You're beating the hell out of a super-powered demigod.
Two: Said super-powered demigod is spouting off the phrase 'I will reveal the power of GOD!'
Three, and most importantly: The ungodly awesome music. Seriously, this is some of the best final boss music out there.
snippet.textOriginal:
Ah, the Zera Valmar fight. I always liked the irony in Zera's name... You know, Pope Zera Innocentus. I loved this fight for multiple reasons.
One: You're beating the hell out of a super-powered demigod.
Two: Said super-powered demigod is spouting off the phrase 'I will reveal the power of GOD!'
Three, and most importantly: The ungodly awesome music. Seriously, this is some of the best final boss music out there.

snippet.textDisplay: It was the last Sega console on the market after the Sega Saturn.  Came out a year before the PS2 but ultimately failed like many other Sega systems unfortunately.  It had some great games like Grandia II, Powerstone 2, Soul Calibur, and Sonic Adventure 2.  Thankfully most of the Dreamcast's good games were ported to other systems :)
snippet.textOriginal: It was the last Sega console on the market after the Sega Saturn.  Came out a year before the PS2 but ultimately failed like many other Sega systems unfortunately.  It had some great games like Grandia II, Powerstone 2, Soul Calibur, and Sonic Adventure 2.  Thankfully most of the Dreamcast's good games were ported to other systems :)

Grandia is a masterful series. III sucked like a bucket of ticks.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm kind of amused you took that as a dis. No, more like a disappointment. The game was otherwise amazing. Great story, nice graphics, I absolutely loved the characters to death. They just could have done better with the battle cries. Please note that I said, in parentheses, "I still love the SoA, though." Seeing as I do love the game as one of my favorites, I'm entitled to any criticism of it I want.

And yes, Grandia 3 was horseshit. I agree wholeheartedly.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm kind of amused you took that as a dis. No, more like a disappointment. The game was otherwise amazing. Great story, nice graphics, I absolutely loved the characters to death. They just could have done better with the battle cries. Please note that I said, in parentheses, "I still love the SoA, though." Seeing as I do love the game as one of my favorites, I'm entitled to any criticism of it I want.

And yes, Grandia 3 was horseshit. I agree wholeheartedly.
